S4.T1.caption: Table 1 :  Objective comparisons of our model with previous lip sync baselines.  MyTalk achieves superior results in visual and lip-sync quality. The state-of-the-art results on visual quality and ID similarity metrics showcase our superiority in preserving visual details.

Pt0.A2.T8.caption: Table 8 :  Statistics of our dataset.

Pt0.A2.T9.caption: Table 9 :  Configuration of MyTalk.

Pt0.A3.T10.caption: Table 10 :  Comparisons with one-stage models.
references:
Firstly, as stated in Sec. 0.B.2, the speech-to-motion generation training dataset is currently limited in size. We plan to expand this dataset to enhance the lip-sync quality and explore the scalability of our method.
Secondly, as detailed in Table 10, our method requires more inference time due to the two-stage modeling. However, MyTalk outperformes other methods in terms of visual quality (PSNR, FID) and ID similarity (IDsim) with a noticeable performance gap, which justifies extra time investment required by MyTalk.
Finally, the current framework leverages a specific pre-trained landmark extractor [42], which may hinder the end-to-end learning of our model. We leave the effectiveness evaluation of our method on alternative types of landmarks (e.g., sparse landmark detected by [21]) and no landmarks (e.g., disentangle the motion and appearance without the help of landmarks) for future work.
